metadata.case_name: Maneklal Ujamshi v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: In 1951, assessee Maneklal Ujamshi gifted 1,184 ordinary and 155 preference shares in Changdeo Sugar Mills Ltd. to his wife Bai Laxmibai. Total value on date of transfer: Rs. 68,730/-

Subsequent to transfer, company converted preference shares into ordinary shares at 8 ordinary shares for each preference share, resulting in Bai Laxmibai holding 2,424 ordinary shares on December 31, 1954
Bai Laxmibai sold 2,400 shares on August 1, 1956 for Rs. 1,54,800/-, resulting in capital gain of Rs. 70,860/- computed under s. 12B of Income-tax Act
Sale proceeds deposited by Bai Laxmibai with M/s. A.H. Bhivandiwalla Co., in which Maneklal and his son Sevantilal were partners, fetching yearly interest of Rs. 9,288/-
For assessment year 1957-58, Income Tax Officer included Rs. 70,860/- (capital gain) in Maneklal's income under s. 16(3)(a)(iii)
For assessment years 1958-59 and 1959-60, Income Tax Officer included Rs. 9,288/- (interest) each year in Maneklal's income under s. 16(3)(a)(iii)

Appeals to Appellate Assistant Commissioner: For 1957-58, appeal dismissed. For 1958-59 and 1959-60, partly allowed; only Rs. 4,183/- (attributable to original gift value Rs. 68,730/-) included each year
Appellate Tribunal: Upheld ITO for 1957-58 (include Rs. 70,860/-). For 1958-59 and 1959-60, allowed Department appeals, included full Rs. 9,288/- each year, dismissed assessee's appeal for 1959-60
Tribunal referred case to Bombay High Court on four questions regarding inclusion under s. 16(3)(a)(iii)

Bombay High Court judgment dated February 19/22, 1965: Q1 (Rs. 70,860/- for 1957-58) answered affirmative against assessee. Q2 and Q4 in favour of assessee against Department. Q3 (Rs. 4,183/- for 1959-60) affirmative in favour of Department
Assessee appealed to Supreme Court by certificate from High Court judgment

legal_issues.text: Whether in computing total income of Maneklal for 1957-58, Rs. 70,860/- (capital gain on sale of gifted shares by wife) properly included under s. 16(3)(a)(iii)
Whether in computing total income for 1958-59, Rs. 5,104/- properly included under s. 16(3)(a)(iii)
Whether in computing total income for 1959-60, Rs. 4,183/- properly included under s. 16(3)(a)(iii)
Whether in computing total income for 1959-60, Rs. 5,105/- properly included under s. 16(3)(a)(iii)

petitioner_arguments.text: Capital gains from sale of transferred assets do not come within s. 16(3)(a)(iii) as it covers income from the assets, not from sale thereof
s. 16(3)(a)(iii) enacted in 1937 when 'income' did not include capital gains (added 1947), so should not cover capital gains

respondent_arguments.text: Capital gain arose directly or indirectly from assets transferred to wife otherwise than for adequate consideration
Interest on deposit of sale proceeds also arose from transferred assets

court_reasoning.text: No logical distinction between income arising from asset and income (capital gain) arising from sale of asset; both spring from the asset
court_reasoning.key_observation: Profits or gains from sale arise or spring from the asset

court_reasoning.text: Though s. 16(3)(a)(iii) enacted pre-1947, 'income' now includes capital gains per s. 2(6C); no reason to exclude from scope
Object of s. 16(3)(a)(iii) is to prevent tax avoidance by transfer to wife; construe to advance remedy

holdings.text: Capital gains from sale of gifted shares by wife arise directly or indirectly from transferred assets and includible in husband's income under s. 16(3)(a)(iii)

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: s. 16(3)(a)(iii) requires inclusion of wife's income arising directly or indirectly from assets transferred by husband without adequate consideration; s. 2(6C) defines income to include capital gains; s. 12B deems capital gains as income

outcome.summary: Supreme Court rejected assessee's arguments and upheld inclusion of capital gain of Rs. 70,860/- in assessee's income for 1957-58 under s. 16(3)(a)(iii), affirming High Court on first question

key_quotes.text: "there is no logical distinction between income arising from the asset transferred to the wife and income arising from the sale of the assets so transferred."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning equating capital gains to income from transferred assets

key_quotes.text: "the object of the enactment of the section is to prevent avoidance of tax or reducing the incidence of tax on the part of the assessee by transfer of his assets to his wife"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose of s. 16(3)(a)(iii) justifying broad interpretation
